timeline.title: Timeline
timeline.puzzleExplanation: The timeline shows the puzzles each team of students were working on at every instant of the CTF. For each solved puzzle, the number of minutes it took each team to solve it is displayed. If a puzzle does not have a number on top, it means that students did not manage to solve it.

api.name: Name
api.authentication: Whether the authentication parameters are correct or not
api.authenticationAPIDesc: This endpoint allows you to authenticate in CAPP The Flag and verify whether you are allowed to participate in an CTF at a given time
api.tokenR: Instead of the password you can provide the user token
api.puzzleAPIDesc: This endpoint allows you to solve puzzles remotely without a need to access CAPP The Flag's team interface
api.startAPIDesc: This endpoint allows you to start participating in an CTF without a need to hit the start button in CAPP The Flag
api.erState: Object indicating the current state of the CTF for the team. It has two properties: puzzlesSolved, which contains an array indicating which puzzles have been completed by the team (including the puzzle's name, number, solution, and success message); hintsAllowed, a boolean indicating whether the team can request any more hints; progress, the percentage of puzzles solved, and score, the total score of the participant according to the grading rubric set up by the teacher.

code.OK: The answer provided for the puzzle is correct
code.NOK: The answer provided for the puzzle is incorrect

api.correctAnswer: Boolean whose value is true if the answer provided for the puzzle is correct and false otherwise.

evaluation.hintFailed: Points for each hint request failed
evaluation.justParticipating: Assign a percentage of the grade just for participating
evaluation.gradingIntro: You can customize a grading scheme to grade the activity
evaluation.title: Evaluation
evaluation.automaticAttendance: Take attendance automatically when a student accesses an CTF during his/her shift
evaluation.automaticAttendanceNone: Do not take attendance automatically whatsoever
evaluation.automaticAttendanceParticipant: Take attendance automatically only for that student
evaluation.automaticAttendanceTeam: Take attendance automatically for the whole team

hints.correctNumberPlaceHolder: How many correct answers do students need to obtain a hint?
hints.explanation: In this step you can select the hint strategy of your CTF. There are three strategies available: not allowing hints, allowing free hints, and requiring students to solve a quiz in order to obtain a hint. If you enable hints, you can set a limit of hints that students can obtain. If you choose the last strategy, you need to upload a MoodleXML file containing a battery of questions and indicate how many questions will be shown each attempt, how many they need to get right in order to pass, and whether the right answer should be shown to them after each attempt
hints.moodleExplanation: If you want students to answer a quiz in order to get a hint, please upload a MoodleXML with a battery of questions
hints.feedbackExplanation: Do you want to show students the correct answers once the quiz is completed?
hints.allowCustomHintsExplanation: If you check this option, when a team runs out of automatic hints, they will be told to ask the teacher for help instead. If not checked, students will not be able to request hints when they run out.
hints.hintIntervalExplanation: How much time (in minutes) do students need to wait before asking for a new hint?
hints.hintLimitExplanation: What is the maximum number of hints students can get?
hints.quizHintsStrategy: Students can obtain hints by passing a quiz
hints.noFile: You haven't uploaded any files yet
hints.questionNumberExplanation: Questions will be randomly picked from the MoodleXML file
hints.questionNumberPlaceHolder: How many questions per attempt do you want?
hints.title: Hint management

team.explanation: Here you can customize the interface that students will see on their computers when they are playing. You can add any information they need in order to participate: links, images, messages, the first clue, etc.
team.placeholder: You can add a custom message, images, links... Do not forget to set up when you want to display this information by clicking in the eye icon on the left.
team.title: Team interface

class.explanation: Here you can customize the interface that you'll be able to screen in the classroom for all students to see. It can include the introductory video, the countdown, the leaderboard, etc. If students are participating in the CTF remotely, they will never see the class interface, so you can skip this step.
class.placeholder: Add the information you want to project in the classroom
class.title: Classroom interface

indications.explanation: Here you can customize the information students will see prior to the start of the CTF since the moment the sign up. For instance, you can remind them to bring certain material, tell them to review the course content, or provide them a video to watch.
indications.title: Pre-activity instructions

front.areYouSureDelete: Are you sure you want to delete this content block? This action cannot be reverted
front.visualizationIntro: When do you wish to display this content block?
front.visualizationSucceed: When students are working on the following puzzles
front.dropHere: Drop now to place the content here

puzzles.explanation: In this step, you can specify the different puzzles that make up the CTF. Bear in mind that they must follow a linear structure, which means that in order to solve a puzzle, students need to have solved the previous one before. You need to specify the name and description of each puzzle, as well as its solution. If you check the automatic monitorization option for any puzzle, it will not be displayed in the team interface for students to solve. Instead, you need to use CAPP The Flag's API in order to solve it. In addition, you may add automatic hints for each puzzle, which will be handed to students when they get stuck and ask for help.

puzzles.notYet: Please create a new puzzle before assigning it any hints

inspiration.intro:
You don't know how to start creating the Escape Room?
Follow these steps
inspiration.title: Escape Room setting up guide

first.title: Step 1: Establish the general approach
first.intro: A good way to start designing an educational Escape Room is to establish how the activity will fit within the subject and thus be able to correctly size the activity.

list.fourth: During class time or outside of this
list.sixth: Resources needed: physical space, use of special material, budget...

second.title: Paso 2: >Step 3: Choose the puzzles
second.intro: Once the activity is defined in the context of the subject in which it will be developed, it is necessary to define what specific contents will cover the Escape Room. As it happens in any other didactic activity. It is recommended to first establish some general objectives and then break them down into more specific objectives that students must achieve to overcome the activity.

third.title: Paso 3: Escoger los retos
third.intro: Based on the objectives established in the previous step, it is necessary to identify the appropriate way to test students' knowledge, combining tasks that involve the practical application of the skills acquired in the subject with theoretical knowledge. The challenges that students face are highly dependent on the subject in which the activity is framed.
third.middle: Some examples of these resources are shown below.

list.assembly: Form the parts of an object

third.resources: Here you can access some resources.

fourth.title: Step 4: Select an appropriate theme
fourth.intro: The theme is one of the key pieces that differentiates an Escape Room from a common practical exercise. It is about the story that surrounds the whole experience and that provides the immersive character of the game. It gives meaning to the tasks that students must perform during the Escape Room and cohesion all the tests of the activity. When you develop the theme you have to take into account:

list.first: The narrative, the temporal and spatial context
list.second: The student profile to which it is addressed
list.third: Consistency between the theme and the chosen challenges
list.fourth: Include the time factor on the subject

fourth.booksAndMovies: A good source of inspiration for selecting a theme is books, video games, famous movies or series, since it is likely that students know the plot or the characters beforehand. Of course, the subject in which the Escape Room is framed will have a great influence on the selection of the theme, since the challenges to overcome must be supported by the narrative. Some examples of themes are:

fifth.title: Step 5: Build challenges, tracks and other materials
fifth.intro: Finally, with the design of the Escape Room and the available resources in mind, it is time to start building all the pieces.

puzzles.title: Puzzles
puzzles.content: To build challenges it is common to use physical resources such as locks, keys, boxes, laboratory equipment, puzzles, etc. However, an Escape Room in which many students participate simultaneously, these types of resources can greatly increase the budget required for the activity. One solution is to combine simple physical resources (paper, for example) with free digital resources: mobile applications, sounds, virtual puzzles, etc. You will find examples and resources in step 3.

hints.title: Hints
hints.content: An essential part in the design of all Escape Rooms are the clues and aids It is essential to avoid that students spend too much time in the same challenge because, if this happens, there is a risk that In addition, this situation can be counterproductive from a pedagogical point of view, since students will not face all the challenges.To prevent the request for help from being constant, one possibility is to devise a battery of questions Students have to try to answer each time they need a clue, and if they can guess more than a certain number of questions, they will get a clue, in this way students will earn the right to get help and their theoretical knowledge is tested. of the subject to complement the practical content that is put into practice in the Escape Room.

instructions.title: Instructions
instructions.intro: Before starting the development of the activity, it is important to present the game to the students, it is important to clarify what the limits of the activity are, if they can leave the room, if they can use their mobile devices, if they can talk with the other teams, etc. Then, they are introduced to the theme presenting the goal to be achieved in the Escape Room and giving indications of where to start, this can be done in the form of video message in which a character (either the teacher or an “actor”) appeals to students to help solve a mystery, crime, enigma, etc. You can also approach from the opposite perspective, showing a video in the that the character plays a villain role that threatens the students.

sixth.title: Step 6: Test the CTF
sixth.intro: Detecting and fixing errors is crucial to the success of an educational Escape Room, since the presence of a failure could have catastrophic consequences in the development of the activity. It is necessary to test the challenges first individually and then perform a complete simulation.

seventh.title: Step 7: Develop a way to evaluate the experience
seventh.intro: There are several ways to evaluate if the students have learned doing the activity, one way is through a control group, comparing the notes of the students who made the CTF with those who did not. at the beginning of the CTF and at the end, checking if there has been a significant increase in the knowledge of the students Finally, at the end of the activity it is convenient to conduct a survey to know the opinion of the students about the CTF.
